_link.title: I can balance simple fission equations

toLevel2.stem: What must be conserved in a balanced nuclear fission equation?
options: Both mass number (A) and atomic number (Z)
toLevel2.explanation: Nuclear equations must conserve both total nucleon number (mass number A) and total charge (atomic number Z).

toLevel2.stem: In the equation ²³⁵U + ¹n → ¹⁴¹Ba + ⁹²Kr + ?n, how many neutrons are released?
What does the superscript number represent in nuclear notation?
toLevel2.explanation: The superscript is the mass number A, representing the total number of nucleons (protons + neutrons).

toLevel2.stem: What does the subscript number represent in nuclear notation?
toLevel2.explanation: The subscript is the atomic number Z, representing the number of protons (which determines the element).

toLevel2.stem: What is the notation for a neutron in nuclear equations?
toLevel2.explanation: A neutron has mass number 1 (one nucleon) and atomic number 0 (no charge): ¹₀n.

toLevel2.stem: In nuclear equations, both [[mass number]] and [[atomic number]] must be conserved.
toLevel2.explanation: Conservation laws require total nucleons (A) and total charge (Z) to be equal on both sides.

toLevel2.stem: The superscript in nuclear notation represents [[mass number (A)]] while the subscript represents [[atomic number (Z)]].
toLevel2.explanation: Standard nuclear notation places A as superscript and Z as subscript before the element symbol.

toLevel2.stem: A neutron is written as [[¹₀n]] with mass number [[1]] and atomic number [[0]].
toLevel2.explanation: The neutron has one nucleon (A=1) but no charge (Z=0).

toLevel2.stem: The total mass number on the left side of a nuclear equation must equal the total on the right side.
toLevel2.explanation: True. Conservation of nucleon number requires equal total A values on both sides.

toLevel2.stem: Only mass number needs to be conserved in nuclear equations, not atomic number.
toLevel2.explanation: False. Both mass number (A) and atomic number (Z) must be conserved in nuclear equations.

toLevel3.stem: Why must atomic number be conserved in nuclear reactions?
options: Electric charge is always conserved in all physical processes
Atomic number is created and destroyed
Only mass matters in nuclear physics
toLevel3.explanation: Charge conservation is a fundamental law of physics. Since protons carry charge, their total must be conserved.

toLevel3.stem: If ²³⁵U undergoes fission, why is the sum of product mass numbers less than 236?
options: Neutrons are released carrying away some of the nucleon count
toLevel3.explanation: The released neutrons carry nucleons away from the fission products, accounting for the difference.

toLevel3.stem: How do you verify that ²³⁵₉₂U + ¹₀n → ¹⁴¹₅₆Ba + ⁹²₃₆Kr + 3¹₀n is balanced?
toLevel3.explanation: Both A and Z must balance: mass (235+1=141+92+3=236) and charge (92+0=56+36+0=92).

toLevel3.stem: What does conservation of mass number actually mean physically?
options: The total number of nucleons (protons + neutrons) is unchanged
The total mass in kg is unchanged
toLevel3.explanation: Mass number counts nucleons. Conservation means no nucleons are created or destroyed, only rearranged.

toLevel3.stem: Why can fission produce different pairs of products from the same uranium isotope?
options: The split can occur at different points along the nucleus
Uranium always splits the same way
toLevel3.explanation: Uranium can split in many different ways, producing various combinations of fission products.

toLevel3.stem: How do you determine the identity of an unknown fission product?
options: Calculate the atomic number Z, then look up which element has that Z
toLevel3.explanation: The atomic number (protons) uniquely identifies each element. Calculate Z by conservation to identify products.

toLevel3.stem: Conservation of [[charge]] requires that total atomic number (Z) is [[unchanged]] in nuclear reactions.
toLevel3.explanation: Electric charge is always conserved; atomic number represents total positive charge from protons.

toLevel3.stem: Released [[neutrons]] account for the difference between uranium's mass number and the sum of [[fission product]] mass numbers.
toLevel3.explanation: Neutrons carry away nucleons, explaining why product masses don't sum to the original nucleus mass.

toLevel3.stem: The [[atomic number]] of a product determines which [[element]] it is.
toLevel3.explanation: Atomic number (proton count) uniquely identifies each element in the periodic table.

toLevel3.stem: Different fission events can produce different product nuclei from the same uranium isotope.
toLevel3.explanation: True. Uranium fission is probabilistic and can produce many different combinations of product nuclei.

toLevel4.stem: Complete: ²³⁵₉₂U + ¹₀n → ¹⁴⁴₅₄Xe + ?₃₈Sr + 2¹₀n. Find the missing Sr isotope.
If ²³⁵U + n → ¹³⁹Ba + X + 3n, what is element X?
toLevel4.explanation: Mass: 236 - 139 - 3 = 94. Charge: 92 - 56 = 36. Element 36 is Kr: ⁹⁴₃₆Kr.

toLevel4.stem: How many neutrons are released in: ²³⁵₉₂U + ¹₀n → ¹⁴⁰₅₄Xe + ⁹⁴₃₈Sr + ?¹₀n?
Balance: ²³⁹₉₄Pu + ¹₀n → ¹⁰³₄₁Nb + ?₅₃I + 4¹₀n. Find the iodine isotope.
Which equation is NOT balanced? A) ²³⁵U + n → ¹⁴¹Ba + ⁹²Kr + 3n, B) ²³⁵U + n → ¹⁴⁴Cs + ⁹⁰Rb + 2n
options: B is unbalanced (Z: 92 ≠ 55+37=92, but let's check A)

toLevel4.stem: A fission product has A = 137 and Z = 55. Which element is this?
toLevel4.explanation: Element 55 in the periodic table is cesium (Cs). The isotope is cesium-137: ¹³⁷₅₅Cs.

toLevel4.stem: In ²³³₉₂U + ¹₀n → ⁹⁰₃₈Sr + ¹⁴¹₅₄Xe + 3¹₀n, verify this is balanced.
toLevel4.explanation: Both mass (234=234) and charge (92=92) are conserved; the equation is balanced.

toLevel4.stem: In ²³⁵U + n → ¹⁴⁴Xe + ⁹⁰Sr + [[2n]], the missing neutrons are found by [[subtracting]] product masses from 236.
To find an unknown element, calculate its [[atomic number (Z)]] by conservation, then use the [[periodic table]].
toLevel4.explanation: Atomic number uniquely identifies elements, which can then be found in the periodic table.

toLevel4.stem: For ²³⁹Pu + n → ¹⁰³Nb + ¹³³I + [[4n]], the neutrons = [[240]] - 103 - 133 = 4.

toLevel5.stem: Analyze why fission products tend to be neutron-rich and therefore radioactive.
options: Heavy nuclei have higher N/Z ratios; products inherit excess neutrons
Fission creates new neutrons inside products
toLevel5.explanation: Heavy nuclei like uranium have N/Z ≈ 1.56; lighter stable nuclei need N/Z ≈ 1. Products must undergo beta decay to stabilize.

toLevel5.stem: How does asymmetric fission (unequal product masses) relate to nuclear shell effects?
options: Products near 'magic numbers' of nucleons are more stable and favored
toLevel5.explanation: Nuclear shell model shows certain nucleon numbers are especially stable. Fission tends to produce fragments near these configurations.

toLevel5.stem: Why might the same fission reaction produce different numbers of neutrons?
options: Product nuclei can be formed in different excited states
toLevel5.explanation: Products form in various excited states; excited products may emit additional neutrons (prompt neutron emission).

toLevel5.stem: Compare how balancing fission equations differs from balancing chemical equations.
options: Fission conserves nucleons; chemical equations conserve atoms and charge
toLevel5.explanation: Fission works at the nucleon level (p,n), while chemistry works at the atomic/molecular level preserving element identity.

toLevel5.stem: How does understanding equation balancing help estimate fission energy release?
options: Mass difference between reactants and products (mass defect) gives energy via E=mc²
Energy cannot be calculated from equations
toLevel5.explanation: Precise masses show reactants exceed product masses; this mass defect converts to ~200 MeV.

toLevel5.stem: Analyze why ternary fission (three product nuclei) is rare compared to binary fission.
options: Three-body breakup is energetically less favorable than two-body
toLevel5.explanation: Splitting into exactly two fragments is the most energetically favorable configuration; three-body events are rare (~0.1%).

toLevel5.stem: How do balanced fission equations help in waste management planning?
options: They identify which radioactive isotopes will be produced and their abundances
toLevel5.explanation: Different fission products have different half-lives and decay modes, affecting storage and handling requirements.

toLevel5.stem: Why is the total actual mass of fission products less than calculated from A values?
options: Mass numbers are integers; actual masses include binding energy differences
toLevel5.explanation: Mass number A counts nucleons as integers, but actual nuclear masses include binding energy contributions (mass defect).

toLevel5.stem: Fission products are [[neutron-rich]] because uranium's high [[N/Z ratio]] is inherited by lighter products.
toLevel5.explanation: Heavy nuclei need more neutrons per proton than light nuclei, leaving fission products neutron-excessive.

toLevel5.stem: The [[mass defect]] between reactant and product masses equals energy released via [[E=mc²]].
toLevel5.explanation: Precise mass differences reveal the binding energy released as kinetic and radiative energy.
